120494 120494 S0926-860X(25)00395-3 10.1016/j.apcata.2025.120494 The Authors Fig. 1 Experimental set-up used for continuous hydrogenation of aqueous levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 FE-SEM image and the corresponding EDX micro-element mapping (C, O, N, P and Ru) of Ru/CNP500 catalyst. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Effect of Ru loading (1–5 wt%) on the NH3-TPD profiles of Ru/CNP500 catalyst (IW denotes Ru/CNP500 catalyst obtained by incipient wetness impregnation and H2 treatment at 400 °C). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) levulinic acid conversion vs. normalized time (time* mmol/gRu) and (b) conversion vs. γ-valerolactone selectivity as function of Ru loading for Ru/CNP500. Reaction conditions: 0.25 g levulinic acid, 5 ml deionised H2O, 15 mg catalyst (Ru/CNP500, Ru loading 1–5 wt%), 5.5 ± 1 bar initial H2, 400 rpm (stirring rate). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 The influence of (a) catalyst acidity (phosphate) upon catalytic performance (γ-valerolactone selectivity) at room temperature (25 ± 2 °C) and (b) reaction temperature upon g-valerolactone selectivity. Reaction conditions: 0.25 g levulinic acid, 5 ml deionised H2O, 15 mg catalyst, 5.5 ± 1 bar initial H2, 400 rpm (stirring rate). Marg, Bhavnagar, 364002 Gujarat, India Herein, a Ru-decorated carbon material bearing unique surface chemistry (Brønsted acidic phosphate groups, Lewis basic N-groups and oxygen functional groups) is shown to exhibit exceptional activity, selectivity and stability upon direct hydrogenation of aqueous levulinic acid (LA) (0.47 M and 0.95 M) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) under mild conditions (25–95 °C and 3.5–5 bar). The multifunctional Ru/carbon catalyst outperformed the bifunctional Ru/NbOPO4, and blended (physically mixed) catalytic systems comprising of commercial Ru/carbon (hydrogenation catalyst) and NbOPO4/Amberlyst 15 (acid promoter/co-catalyst). The material also demonstrated remarkable stability for energy efficient GVL production in a fixed-bed reactor under continuous flow conditions, maintaining stable GVL productivity during 52-day time on stream operating at 3.5–5 bar, 80–95 °C and low H2/LA ratio (4–17:1 mol/mol). The exceptional catalytic performance and long term stability of the multifunctional carbocatalyst was attributed to the presence of highly active Ru(0) nanoparticles stabilized on N-doped carbon framework and acidic phosphates and RuOx/RuO2 sites, which promote LA hydrogenation and intramolecular esterification of 4-hydroxypenatonnic (4-HPA) in tandem, affording a high GVL selectivity. The catalyst’s combination of high productivity, long-term stability, and ability work under intensified setting in mid conditions highlight its potential for energy efficient GVL production at large scale. Graphical Abstract Keywords Selective hydrogenation γ-valerolactone Levulinic acid Ru-based catalysts Multifunctional catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The transformation of non-edible biomass into value-added chemicals, fuels, and materials has garnered significant interest due to the depletion of crude oil reserves. Consequently, the production of alcohols [1,2], short-chain hydrocarbons [3,4] 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) [5,6], and organic acids [7–10] from renewable biomass have attracted growing attention. In this context, a key platform chemical (i.e., LA) can be derived from carbohydrates such as cellulose and hemicellulose, which together constitute approximately 65–85 wt% of lignocellulose [11]. The LA serves as a versatile precursor for the synthesis of sustainable, high-value chemicals such as GVL. The GVL and its derivatives have emerged as multifunctional compounds with a broad range of applications: as solvents [12–14], components in battery electrolytes [15], precursors for bulk chemicals (e.g., adipic acid and pentanoic acid) [16,17], food additives [13,18,19], and fuel additives [18] in gasoline-ethanol blends. Therefore, the selective and efficient conversion of aqueous LA to GVL has become a key focus in advancing sustainable biorefineries [20]. The conversion of lignocellulosic feedstocks into γ-valerolactone (GVL) typically involves a two-step process. In the first stage, levulinic acid (LA) is produced through acid hydrolysis of the holocellulose fraction in biomass [20]. In the subsequent step, LA undergoes a cascade of hydrogenation and dehydration steps or dehydration and hydrogenation, passing through either 4- hydroxypentanoic acid (HPA) or angelica lactone (AL) as an intermediate to produce GVL ( Scheme 1). In recent decades, catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) has gained interest due to its non-reliance on fossil fuel-derived hydrogen. However, CTH brings new challenges, such as the requirement of high-purity anhydrous feed, additional product separation, hydrogen donor regeneration, and reactor corrosion (especially when formic acid is used as an H2 donor) [21–23]. Further, use of harsh reaction conditions (1–5 MPa and ∼90–200 °C) have been reported in the traditional synthesis of LA to GVL regardless of whether CTH or molecular H2 is employed [16,24,25]. While such conditions can reduce reaction time and lead to enhanced GVL yields, they highlight the importance of developing robust catalysts that enable efficient GVL production under milder temperatures and lower hydrogen pressures. This is especially relevant for reducing reliance on fossil fuel-derived brown hydrogen and enhancing the overall economic viability of the process. The production of GVL from LA is facilitated by the bi-functional metal-supported catalyst sustaining the hydrogenation and acid driven reactions. In such catalysts, the hydrogenation function is provided by the metal nanoparticles in its reduced form affording hydrogenation of LA to HPA, while acidic sites promote conversion of HPA to GVL (Scheme 1) [24]. In this regard, a variety of supported noble metal and transition metal-based catalysts have been employed for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. Ru appears to be the most active and selective metal (especially in water), owing to its unique ability to selectively hydrogenate carbonyl groups. For instance, Manzer et al. reported the robust activity over supported Ru compared to other candidates (Ir, Rh, Pd, Pt, Re, Ni). However, supported Ru catalysts have been previously reported to possess stability issues due to the sintering, leaching, and coking [20–26]. For instance, commercial Ru/C is highly active in LA to GVL, although it has demonstrated poor stability in both batch and continuous systems [26]. Therefore, the need for a robust supported Ru catalyst is still of significant commercial importance. On the contrary, the acidity is provided majorly by the support, which does the intra-molecular esterification of 4-HPA to GVL. Although inorganic metal oxides (TiO2, ZrO2, Al2O3, SiO2, Nb2O5, MgO, ZnO, CeO2) possess the higher stability to undergo regeneration (i.e., coking on spent catalyst) at decoking conditions [16], supported carbon supports had previously been reported to outperform the former supports. This agrees with the observation of Piskun et al. where their supported Ru on carbon (CNT, C) showed higher conversion of LA compared to TiO2, ZrO2, Al2O3, ZrO2, Nb2O5. The authors observed Ru supported on CNT showed higher activity compared to C during the conversion of LA to GVL at 90 °C and 45 bar H2. The difference in activity was arguably due to higher H2 adsorption capacity [16]. Similarly, the variation in the nature of carbon supports (Ir, Pd supported on CNT and AC) influencing the catalytic performance was highlighted in the work of Xianlong et al. [27]. The bifunctional role of the supported carbon catalyst could be altered depending upon the functionalization/doping with P, S, and N, which alter the acid-base properties of the resulting catalyst, thereby improving the LA conversion and GVL selectivity. For example, incorporating of phosphates increases the acidity of carbon support post-functionalization, which favors the acid-catalyzed conversion of HPA into GVL [28,29]. Complete conversion was achieved at 70 °C, 7 bar, and 6–9 h. Recently attempts have also been made towards the application of bifunctional Ru catalysts based on inexpensive sulfonic resins (e.g., polyethersulfone, DOWEX 50WX2), SO3H functionalized mesoporous carbons, and exotic materials like graphene, graphene-oxide, metal organic frameworks as well as inorganic solid acids based on NbOPO4 and NbOPO4/SiO2 materials as supports [30–33]. Although sulfur doping results in even higher acidity compared to phosphorus, it leads to poor LA conversion due to unfavorable interactions between sulfur and the active transition metal, which diminishes the catalyst’s hydrogenation function. In contrast, nitrogen doping was reported to favor electron modulation between carbon, nitrogen, and metal particles, thereby boosting the hydrogenation performance of the catalyst [24]. Therefore, carbon supports owing to their functionalization capability, synergistic effect, higher surface area, and high availability had piqued interest in the LA to GVL [25]. These characteristics provide higher stability for supported metal and lower intra-particle diffusional limitations of the reactants depending upon the nature of the carbon support [16]. Additionally, the ability to derive functionalized carbon support from agricultural by-products and biomass waste adds to their economic and environmental appeal [25]. Nevertheless, the addition of unpromoted solid Brønsted acid catalyst (Amberlyst-15, H-Y, H-beta, and H-ZSM-5) by physically mixing with bi-functional catalyst has become a practice to lower the reaction temperature [34]. The former provides the additional acidity to boost the conversion of 4-HPA (hydrogenated intermediate of LA) to GVL. This conversion step was previously obtained using higher reaction temperatures due to faster dehydration kinetics instead of using a solid acid catalyst. However, regenerating such physical mixtures presents certain challenges. The solid acid component, which lacks hydrogenation function may accumulate coke or strongly bind oxygenated species that require higher regeneration temperatures than those suitable for the bifunctional catalyst. This difference in regeneration conditions can lead to catalyst deactivation and result in unstable performance over multiple reaction cycles. Hence, the development of practical, efficient and stable bifunctional Ru incorporating chemically stable acids sites for selective low temperature hydrogenation of aqueous levulinic acid to GVL is still a major technical challenge. Recently, in many industrially important reactions (such as oxidation, deoxygenation and hydrogenolysis), direct correlation could be established between the surface acid-base properties of carbon carriers (supports) with the activity, selectivity and stability of metal (Au, Pd, Ru) supported carbon catalysts. In addition, the nature of surface defects on carbon carriers are also shown to influence the stability, dispersion and particle size of metal nanoparticles [30,35–39]. In the view of the points disused above, within this work we have developed a highly porous multifunctional Ru/C catalyst incorporating unique surface properties (oxygen functional groups, strongly Brønsted acidic non-reducible phosphate sites and abundant Lewis basic N-sites) as an alternative catalyst for selective, low temperature hydrogenation of aqueous LA streams to GVL. Considering the important effects of carbon-support surface properties, we also explored the role of carbon support surface chemistry upon the performance of Ru-catalysts for GVL production. Most importantly, herein we corroborate the industrial feasibility of a bio-waste (chitin) derived low-cost, multifunctional Ru/carbon catalyst, from extended stability tests conducted in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor (∼1250 h time on stream) and using a varied H2:LA mole ratio (≤17) under mild conditions (3–3.5 bar and 80–95 °C). 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals NaOH (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), H3PO4 (85 %, VWR), HCl (37 %, Merck), chitin flakes (from shrimp shells, Sigma-Aldrich), ammonium dihydrogen phosphate (99.9 %, Merck), Amberlyst 15 (dry, H+ form, Sigma-Aldrich), silica-alumina (Sigma-Aldrich), levulinic acid (LA) (97 %, Sigma-Aldrich), γ-valerolactone (GVL) (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), niobium(V)chloride (99.8 %, ACROS), ruthenium chloride (RuCl3.xH2O, abcr GmbH, 36 % Ru) were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. 2.2 Catalytic materials The bifunctional carbon support containing nitrogen and phosphorus sites were obtained by the one step phosphoric acid activation of chitin according to the procedures described in our earlier works [40,41]. In a typical synthesis procedure, 10 g of chitin flakes were soaked with 50 % aqueous phosphoric acid solution in 1:2 (w/w) ratio and aged for 24 h under ambient conditions. In the next step, the chitin-phosphoric acid mixture was transferred into an alumina crucible, loaded into a muffle furnace (Nabertherm, LT15) and activated at 500 °C (heating rate 3 °C/min) for 1 h in the self-generated atmosphere. The obtained materials were ground to powder and thoroughly washed with hot deionized water (90 °C) until neutral pH and dried in an oven at 100 °C for 24 h to produce the bifunctional carbon supports (CNP500) containing nitrogen (basic), oxygen and phosphorus (acidic) functional groups. A reference carbon material (CN650) without phosphorus doping was obtained by the direct carbonization of chitin flakes at 650 °C according to procedures described in our earlier report [42]. The basic carbon support containing only nitrogen sites was obtained by the direct carbonization of chitin flakes. In a typical synthesis procedure, 10 g of chitin flakes were loaded onto an alumina boat, transferred into a tubular furnace (Carbolite) and carbonized under 50 ml/min N2 flow at 350 °C (heating rate 2.5 °C/min) for 2 h. The thus obtained carbon materials were further carbonized at 650 °C for 1.5 h (heating rate 5 °C/min, 50 ml/min N2). The resulting carbon materials were powdered and washed with deionized water and dried overnight at 100 °C to obtain the basic carbon support (CNP500) functionalized with nitrogen functional groups [42,43]. The carbon support containing oxygen functional groups and trace amount of phosphates (CPcomm) was obtained from Fisher scientific and used without any modifications. The Nb based support, NbP-bulk (NbOPO4) was prepared according to the procedures described in literature (hydrolysis of niobium(V)chloride in 12 M HCl in the presence of stoichiometric amount of ammonium dihydrogen phosphate, followed by calcination at 400 °C) [30]. The loaded catalyst Ru/NbP-bulk catalyst was obtained by incipient wetness impregnation of RuCl3 according to the procedures described elsewhere. Prior to use the catalytic material was reduced at 400 °C, under a stream of pure H2. The Ru loaded carbon catalysts (Ru/CN650, Ru/CNP500, and Ru/CPcomm) were prepared by employing the well-known deposition-precipitation method described in literature [42,44]. The synthesis procedure for supported catalyst was as follows: 1 g carbon support was added to 50 ml deionised water under stirring, at room temperature. After stirring for 1 h, an appropriate amount of ruthenium chloride (aqueous) solution (2.5 mg/ml corresponding to metal loading of 1–5 wt%) was added to the mixture/suspension and stirred for 2 h, at room temperature. Next, 0.1 M NaOH was slowly added to the reaction mixture to adjust the pH of the solution to ∼9.5. After further stirring the resulting mixture for 1 h, a calculated amount of freshly prepared NaBH4 solution (nNaBH4/nRu = 15/1) was rapidly added into this solution and further stirred for 1 h at room temperature. To obtain the desired catalytic materials, the contents of the reaction mixture were filtered and extensively washed with deionized water until free from Cl- ions and dried under a stream of N2 at 70 °C for 24 h. A reference catalyst Ru/CNP500_IW was also prepared following the incipient wetness impregnation and H2 reduction technique described above for Ru/NbP-bulk. The actual metal Ru loadings measured by ICP-OES, were identical to the designed loadings in all the catalysts. The commercial ruthenium catalyst (Ru/CSigma) with 5 wt% ruthenium loading and oxygen functionalized active carbon supports were obtained from Sigma Aldrich and used as received. 2.3 Catalytic reaction procedures Batch experiments were performed in a custom-made mini autoclave (∼13 ml) assembled from Swagelok parts with stoichiometric amount of H2. The reactor was equipped with a pressure gauge, inlet and outlet valves. In a typical experiment, after loading the reactor with the desired amount of catalyst (15–30 mg), levulinic acid (0.25 g) and water (5 g), the reactor was sealed and purged up to 5 times with pure H2 gas. In the next step, the reactor was pressurized to the desired initial H2 pressure (5.5 ± 1 bar or ∼2.5 mmol H2). To initiate the reaction, the contents of the reactor were heated to the desired reaction temperature (85 °C) in a sand bath under magnetic stirring (500 rpm) for an appropriate duration. After the completed reaction, the reactor was cooled under tap water, the residual H2 carefully released, and the liquid contents centrifuged to separate the catalyst. In a typical fixed bed experiment, the dry catalyst (1–1.6 g, ≥150 µm) was packed into the custom made tubular mini reactor (12 mm OD, 10 mm ID and length 16 cm) assembled from high pressure 316 stainless-steel tubing, tube fittings and valves purchased from Swagelok ( Fig. 1). The reactor temperature was maintained (80–95 °C) using band heaters and the total pressure (3–5 bar) controlled using a Back-Pressure Regulator (Equilibar U3L Series Precision Back Pressure Regulator). The liquid feed (0.47 or 0.95 M levulinic acid) was pumped continuously into the reactor using an HPLC pump (Perkin Elmer series 200 micro pump), while H2 was simultaneously supplied using a mass flow controller (Bronkhorst EL-FLOW® Select). In a typical experiment, the system was initially degassed with N2 at 10 ml min−1 flow for 1 h, then the flow was switched to H2 and the flow rate adjusted for obtaining the desired H2: levulinic acid (molar ratio) and reactor heated to the desired temperature, after which the liquid feed was pumped continuously. For determining the conversion and selectivity, the liquid aliquots/solutions collected from batch and continuous flow experiments were periodically analyzed by HPLC (Agilent Technologies 1200 Series, RID detector, Aminex HPX-87H Column) and GC-FID (Agilent 7820 A GC, HP-5MS capillary column, 30 m length, 0.25 mm internal diameter, 0.25 μm film thickness), the quantification of individual components in the liquid-phase mixture were based on calibration curves obtained with commercially available compounds. To check for Ru leaching, liquid aliquots were also periodically analyzed by ICP-OES on a PerkinElmer (OPTIMA 2000 DV) instrument. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic materials characterization In this work, we prepared a series of bifunctional Ru-catalyst using porous supports of varying surface acidities. Table 1 presents a summary of the textural and surface acid-base properties of the different support materials used in the work. From the data presented in Table 1, we can see that NbP-bulk presented the most acidic surface with abundant strong Brønsted sites (Nb2O5 and NbOPO4), while the carbon materials (CPcomm, CNP500, and CN650) presented a highly functionalized surface comprising of neutral, weakly acidic, moderately Brønsted acidic, and Lewis basic sites [40,41]. The carbon support obtained by chitin pyrolysis (CN650) presented surface comprising of natural, weakly acidic and basic sites (attributed to the presence of –COOH, –OH, pyridinic nitrogen, pyrrolic/pyridonic nitrogen and N oxide of pyridinic nitrogen species), while the carbon material obtained by phosphoric acid activation of chitin (CNP500) presented a diverse multifunctional surface chemistry comprising of neutral-to-weakly acidic oxygen functional groups, moderately Brønsted acidic phosphate sites and basic pyridinic, pyrrolic/pyridonic, quaternary and N oxide of pyridinic nitrogen sites (Table 1) [40–43]. In contrast, the commercial active carbon (CPcomm) presented an acidic surface comprising of only oxygen and trace amount of phosphorus functional groups. Table 2 summarizes the textural properties, dispersion, and average metal particle size of supported Ru-catalysts using the different supports discussed above, in comparison to the commercial Ru/C (Sigma). The carbon-based catalytic materials were synthesized following the standard deposition-precipitation of RuCl3 followed by borohydride reduction [44]. In contrast, the Ru/NbP-bulk catalyst was obtained by incipient wetness impregnation of RuCl3 according to the procedures described in our earlier work [45]. From the data presented in Table 2, the importance of the carbon support surface chemistry on metal particle dispersion and average metal particle size is clearly seen. The presence of surface functional groups, especially acidic oxides (Nb2O5, and NbOPO4) and Lewis basic nitrogen sites was clearly favorable for the formation of uniformly dispersed and small metal (Ru) nanoparticles, similar to the trends observed in literature. The effect was clearly noticeable for NbP-bulk, CN650 and CNP500 whereupon highly dispersed (37–76 %) and ultra-small Ru nanoparticles (1.76–3.63 nm) were obtained at 2.5–5 wt% Ru loading (Table 2). The presence of well dispersed Ru species and the uniform distribution of surface functional groups comprising of nitrogen, oxygen and phosphate sites could also be confirmed from the EDX microelement (Ru, P, O, C and N) mapping images illustrated in Fig. 2. Furthermore, from the NH3-acidity values presented in Table 2 and NH3-TPD profiles in Fig. 3, a positive effect of Ru nanoparticles immobilization upon catalyst surface acidity was clearly observed. The enhanced acidity of Ru-loaded catalysts could be attributed to the presence of Lewis acidic of RuO2/RuOx species [37,38]. In fact, a combination of Ru/RuOx species loaded on carbon supports have been previously employed as an effective bifunctional catalyst for glycerol hydrogenolysis, acetylene hydrochlorination and furfural hydrodeoxygenation [37–39]. 3.2 Catalytic activity in batch In order to evaluate the catalyst properties upon hydrogenation of aqueous LA, preliminary catalytic tests were conducted in batch mode using near stoichiometric amount of H2 (5.5 ± 1 bar or ca. 2.5 mmol) at 80 °C. The results from batch experiments presented in Table 3, confirm the positive effect of catalyst acidity in terms of GVL selectivity. The activity/selectivity trends observed with the multifunctional Ru-catalysts incorporating phosphate sites (Ru/NbP-bulk, Ru/CNP500 and Ru/CPcomm) were comparable with the selectivity trends of Brønsted acid (Amberlyst 15 and NbOPO4) promoted Ru/C (Sigma) catalyzed hydrogenation of LA, in agreement with the role of strong/moderately Brønsted acidic surface acid sites as a co-catalysts for the dehydration of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid as, also reported in earlier works (Scheme 1)[46–48] Interestingly, we observed a positive correlation between conversion, and GVL selectivity with increasing Ru loading ( Fig. 4), in agreement with the acidity trends presented in Table 2 and Fig. 3, and the Lewis acidity of RuO2/RuOx species [37,38]. In addition, the method of catalyst preparation also had impact on the acidity of supported Ru catalysts which, in turn, influenced the catalyst activity (LA conversion, GVL yield and selectivity). In this work, the catalysts prepared by incipient wetness impregnation and H2 reduction (Ru/CNP500_IW) presented ca. two-fold lower activity than the Ru/CNP500 catalyst obtained by deposition-precipitation technique resulting from 3.5-fold lower NH3 acidity of the former (Fig. 3, Tables 2 and 3). The Lewis acidity of RuO2/RuOx species also accounts for the rather high (90 %) γ-valerolactone selectivity observed at 80 °C for the Ru/C (Sigma) catalyst incorporating only oxygen functional groups, while the presence of surface Lewis basic sites alone of were clearly detrimental for GVL production as observed for Ru/CN650 (Entry 2, Table 3). The influence of catalyst surface acidity on GVL selectivity was more clearly noticeable at room temperature, whereupon Ru/Csigma presented ca. ∼1.6-fold lower GVL selectivity than the multifunctional Ru/CNP500 and Ru/CPcomm catalysts incorporating phosphate sites ( Fig. 5(a) and Table 3). The positive effect of reaction temperature on GVL selectivity could also be observed from plots in Fig. 5(b). It is also important to highlight here that in all catalytic experiments only stoichiometric amount of H2 was consumed producing GVL and intermediate 4-hydroxypentanoic acid, consistent with the selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid under the mild experimental conditions [29,32,47,49]. Reuse was also possible for the carbon-based multifunctional catalyst (Ru/CNP500) with no activity loss during multiple recycles, similar to the bifunctional mixtures of (Ru/Csigma+Amberlyst 15) and (Ru/Csigma+NbP-bulk). However, the NbOPO4 based bifunctional catalyst (Ru/NbP-bulk) demonstrated a steady activity loss (ca. 3–3.5 %) with each recycle, most likely due to factors like sintering or loss of active Ru nanoparticles ( Fig. 6(a)) [49–51] 3.3 Catalytic activity in continuous flow Motivated by the promising results obtained in batch mode, we decided to further explore the low temperature hydrogenation activity of multifunctional Ru/CNP500 catalyst under continuous flow conditions, the stability of bifunctional mixtures of (Ru/Csigma+Amberlyst 15) and (Ru/Csigma+NbP-bulk) were also explored for the sake of comparison (Ru loading was 5 wt%, in all the catalysts). Catalytic experiments were conducted in a custom-made down flow fixed-bed reactor allowing for a concurrent flow of H2 and liquid feed (0.49–0.96 M aqueous LA), keeping reaction conditions similar to those of batch operations. Representative results from fixed-bed experiments are summarized in Table 4, which confirm the exceptional catalytic performance of multifunctional Ru/CNP500 catalyst upon GVL production, which was on par to the bifunctional mixtures of commercial Ru/Csigma with acid co-catalysts, in terms of conversion and selectivity. The data presented in Table 4 also confirms the possibility of tuning both LA conversion and GVL yield/selectivity by simple adjustment of flow rate of liquid feed (liquid hourly space velocity/residence time), gaseous H2 (H2/levulinic acid mole ratio) and reaction temperature and pressure. In terms of GVL productivity ( g GVL g Ru − 1 h − 1 ) , even though the blended catalytic systems outperformed the multifunctional Ru/CNP500 (Table 4), the latter was clearly more advantageous in terms of long-term stability resulting from the enhanced stabilization of Ru-nanoparticles over a highly nitrogen doped carbon surface (see below) [35,36,42]. Another advantage of the Ru/CNP500 catalyst was its ability to work with aqueous LA with concentrations ranging from 0.48 to 0.96 M (56 g/L-112 g/L), representing realistic LA feed obtained from biomass processing, a major improvement over the Ru@DOWEX catalyst utilizing extremely diluted 0.23 g/L (0.02 M) LA as a substrate [32]. To evaluate the lifetime/stability of catalytic systems, catalytic reactions under fixed-bed conditions were continuously monitored at fixed liquid hourly space velocity, H2/levulinic acid mole ratio and fixed temperature for at least 12 h or, until steady deactivation was observed (decay of GVL selectivity and LA conversion). If no deactivation was observed during ∼120 h operation, reaction conditions such as temperature, liquid hourly space velocity, H2/ levulinic acid mole ratio and liquid feed concentration were adjusted to evaluate the effect of these parameters on the stability of catalyst (see below). It is also important to emphasize here that the catalysts reported herein worked at very low H2/LA (mole) ratio 4–17:1, substantially lower than the benchmark bifunctional catalyst (Ru@DOWEX) reported for continuous GVL production, operating a with H2/LA (mole) ratio 54–95:1 [32]. Comparison of the time on stream data obtained for hydrogenation of 0.48 M levulinic acid at 85 °C for the blended catalytic systems (Ru/Csigma+Amberlyst 15 and Ru/Csigma+NbP-bulk) with Ru/CNP500, further confirm the superiority and versatility of the multifunctional catalyst showing no signs of deactivation during 120 h operation, in contrast the bifunctional mixtures showed significant activity loss at ca. 10 h and ∼35 h for (Ru/Csigma+NbP-bulk) and (Ru/Csigma+Amberlyst 15), respectively (Fig. 6(b)). Due to the low pH of feed, in this work we opted for deactivation studies at full conversion to minimize/suppress the leaching of Ru through the formation of Ru–carboxylate complexes with levulinic acid (pKa ∼4.59) in liquid phase [49–51]. Nevertheless, the activity loss of bifunctional mixtures could be attributed mainly to the sintering of Ru nanoparticles, and also partially to the formation of metal sulfides under reducing H2 atmosphere for the Ru/Csigma+Amberlyst 15 system, as ICP-OES analysis revealed no leaching of Ru species [29]. Nevertheless, motivated by the exceptional stability of Ru/CNP500 catalyst under operational conditions, extended stability tests were conducted with the same catalyst without any regeneration or pretreatment by varying reaction conditions to further investigate the influence of reaction parameters and feed concentration on catalyst stability. From the data presented in Table 4, and the time on stream plots for 5 % Ru/CNP500 in Fig. 7, it could be seen that during 1250 h (52 days) operation, LA conversion was stable and close ∼100 %, irrespective of the reaction temperature, pressure, weight hourly space velocity, and liquid feed concentration. Nevertheless, a slight decrease (ca. 10 %) in GVL selectivity was observed upon switching from 0.48 M to 0.96 M levulinic acid feed and the selectivity could be increased to the desired levels ≥ 90 % by either increasing the reaction temperature or reducing weight hourly space velocity of the liquid feed. The decreased selectivity could be attributed to lack of sufficient moderate acid (phosphate) sites to promote cyclization of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid. Nevertheless, the ∼100 % LA conversion, observed was in good agreement with the kinetically favorable hydrogenation of carbonyl carbon of LA, and the high catalytic activity of small Ru-nanoparticles (∼3.6 nm) deposited on the multifunctional carbon support CNP500 (Tables 2 and 3)[46]. However, upon lowering the H2/levulinic acid (mole) ratio to 4:1, conversion of LA reduced to 85 %, but GVL selectivity stabilized at the desired levels (≥90 %) and, most importantly, both the conversion and selectivity remained unaffected during ∼30 h operation under these conditions (Fig. 7), highlighting the stability of catalyst in the presence of unconverted LA. Reaction pressure was found have positive influence on as shown in Table 3 and Fig. 7, however the application of H2 pressures greater than 5 bar was avoided in this study. Overall, these results of the extended stability test confirm the exceptional performance of developed multifunctional Ru/CNP500 (Ru loading was 5 %) catalyst for continuous hydrogenation of aqueous LA (0.48 M to 0.96 M) to GVL under mild process conditions. Overall, the exceptional catalytic performance and durability of the Ru/CNP500 catalyst could be attributed to the enhanced stabilization of Ru-nanoparticles over the nitrogen surface defects, which prevent nanoparticles aggregation and leaching, thus inhibiting deactivation [35,36,42]. Most importantly, unlike the bifunctional Ru catalysts incorporating unstable and reducible SO3H groups as the acidic sites, the acidic phosphate sites of multifunctional Ru/CNP500 catalysts were non-reducible and chemically stable under the experimental conditions [28,29,31,32]. 3.4 Discussion and characterization of spent catalyst The experimentally observed activity, selectivity and stability of Ru/CNP500 catalyst was further supported form the characterization results of spent catalyst collected from the fixed after 1250 h time on stream, while the absence of Ru-species leaching was confirmed by ICP-OES analysis of collected liquid products at regular intervals. A comparison of the TEM images shows that even after 52 day continuous operation (∼1250 h time on stream) under varying conditions of pressure, temperature, H2 and LA flow rate, aggregation or sintering of nanoparticles was almost non-observable ( Fig. 8), consistent with observed trends of catalyst performance in Fig. 7. However, the NH3-TPD patterns of the spent catalyst revealed a slight shifting of the medium temperature desorption peak to a higher temperature, which could be attributed to the partial reduction of RuOx/RuO2 species to metallic Ru ( Fig. 9(a)). Comparison of the textural properties obtained from N2-physiorption confirm that the material retained its mesoporous structure, 53 % of its specific surface area and 62 % of its pore volume even after prolonged use (52 days) under varying experiential conditions. The slight reduction in porosity and specific surface area was most likely linked with the strongly chemisorbed oxygenated molecules on catalyst surface functional groups which blocked access to the smaller micropores (Table 2 and Fig. 9(b)). Further confirmation on the hypothesis regarding the presence of adsorbed organic species and the exceptional stability of immobilized Ru-nanoparticles, were obtained from the XPS surface analysis. Comparison of the high resolution of XPS spectra C1s, O1s, N1s, P2p and Ru3d region of spent Ru/CNP500, with the as synthesized Ru/CNP500, also revealed only minor compositional changes upon the surface chemistry CNP500 even after 52 days upon continuous operation and γ-valerolactone production ( Fig. 10). As expected, the C1s region revealed a slight increase in the intensity of C1s (CO) peaks, reflected by a ca. 4 % increase in the carbon content, consistent with the strong adsorption of product molecule GVL (Fig. 10(a)). A comparison of the O1s region revealed a decrease in the intensity of O1s (=O) peak, which could be attributed to reduction of surface RuO2/RuOx species to metallic Ru, the removal of surface oxygenates (such as COOH, OH) are unlikely considering the mild reaction conditions (Fig. 10(b)). The N1s region did not show a marked change and retained ca. 70 % of its sites, even after 52 day continuous operation under reducing (H2 rich) conditions (Fig. 10(c)). A comparison of P2p region revealed a significant reduction (ca. 65 %) in the phosphate content, which could be attributed to hydrolytic cleavage of some of the C-P or C-O-P linkages under hydrothermal environments (Fig. 10(d)). Even so, the material retained adequate amount of Brønsted acidic phosphate sites to promote efficient dehydration of HPA to GVL up to ∼1250 h time on stream. Most importantly, these acidic phosphate sites were non-reducible, even in the presence of excess H2, at elevated temperatures (80–95 °C), which addresses the drawback of permanent deactivation observed for bifunctional Ru-catalysts based on sulfated supports [29,31,32,46,49–51]. Finally, a comparison of the Ru3d peaks of spent and fresh Ru/CNP500 revealed no net decrease in the Ru content (Fig. 10(a)), in agreement with the ICP-OES analysis (conducted at regular intervals), while the presence of metallic Ru(0) in spent catalyst was attributed to the reduction of RuO2/RuOx species under reducing conditions. Based on the experimental findings, a plausible mechanism can be proposed for multifunctional Ru/CNP500 catalyzed hydrogenation of LA to GVL, where upon LA hydrogenation to HPA was catalyzed by Ru(0) particles stabilized on N-sites of carbon and the intramolecular esterification of the intermediate HPA to GVL was catalyzed by the Brønsted acidic phosphate and Lewis acidic RuO2/RuOx species present in same material ( Scheme 2). Overall, Ru/CNP500 represents one of the most active, stable and economical Ru-catalyst for continuous hydrogenations of LA to GVL easily outperforming Ru@DOWEX and Ru/NbOPO4/SBA-15 in terms of GVL productivity, long-term durability and energy efficiency (requirement of milder temperature and pressure and low H2 stoichiometry) [30,32]. Furthermore, the unique ability of the catalyst to work with low pressure H2 streams and low H2/feed ratio may enable development of a hydrogenation reactor capable of directly utilizing renewable H2 from water electrolysis for GVL production. Furthermore, to confirm the industrial utility of demonstrated process, we also examined the tandem conversion of the crude 9 wt% aqueous GVL (containing 90 % GVL and 10 % HPA as organics) obtained over Ru/CNP500 catalyst into C8+ branched olefins in a cascade process following a procedure similar to Dumesic et al. [17,19] and Peters et al. [52] (Fig. S1, supporting information). However, unlike the previous processes operating at high pressures (e.g., 36 bar) and concentrated feeds (30 % or higher), the process reported herein operated at atmospheric pressure with a single pass, dual-bed reactor system comprising of a commercial silica-alumina (1st bed) and solid phosphoric acid (2nd bed) (Fig. S2, supporting information), also the process directly used the 9 wt% aqueous γ-valerolactone obtained from the hydrogenation reactor without any pretreatments. Interestingly, the use of lower pressure and a dilute γ-valerolactone feed prevented the deactivation of Silica-Alumina catalyst as observed by Dumesic et al. [17] (Fig. S2, supporting information) and continuously afforded a mixture of C8 to C12 branched olefins suitable for upgradation to aviation grade gasoline. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a bio-waste (chitin) derived multifunctional Ru-catalyst (Ru/CNP500) incorporating moderately Brønsted acidic phosphate sites, Lewis basic N-sites and surface oxygenates is shown to exhibit exceptional activity, and stability upon selective hydrogenation of aqueous LA to GVL under mild reaction conditions (80–95 °C, stoichiometric or low H2/feed ratio). The multifunctional catalyst outperformed the bifunctional Ru-catalysts based on NbOPO4 and blended catalytic systems comprising commercial Ru/carbon as the hydrogenation catalyst and NbOPO4/Amberlyst 15 as an acid co-catalyst. Most importantly, the catalytic material demonstrated remarkable stability in a fixed-bed reactor under continuous flow conditions, maintaining high activity and stable GVL selectivity/yield during 52 day operation at 3–5 bar, 80–95 °C and low H2/levulinic acid ratio (4−17). The exceptional catalytic performance and stability of the multifunctional Ru-catalyst was attributed to the unique surface chemistry of carbon support that stabilized the small Ru nanoparticles on the various surface nitrogen and oxygen defects and promoted HPA cyclization over the acidic phosphate sites. Moreover, the acidic phosphate sites of the multifunctional Ru/CNP500 catalyst were non-reducible and chemically stable under the reaction conditions, unlike the previously reported sulfated bifunctional Ru-catalysts incorporating unstable and reducible SO3H groups as the acidic sites. Furthermore, due the unique ability of the catalyst to work with low pressure H2 streams and low H2/feed ratio may even enable development of a small-scale hydrogenation reactor for sustainable GVL production utilizing green H2 from water electrolysis. coredata.dc:description: Herein, a Ru-decorated carbon material bearing unique surface chemistry (Brønsted acidic phosphate groups, Lewis basic N-groups and oxygen functional groups) is shown to exhibit exceptional activity, selectivity and stability upon direct hydrogenation of aqueous levulinic acid (LA) (0.47 M and 0.95 M) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) under mild conditions (25–95 °C and 3.5–5 bar). The multifunctional Ru/carbon catalyst outperformed the bifunctional Ru/NbOPO4, and blended (physically mixed) catalytic systems comprising of commercial Ru/carbon (hydrogenation catalyst) and NbOPO4/Amberlyst 15 (acid promoter/co-catalyst). The material also demonstrated remarkable stability for energy efficient GVL production in a fixed-bed reactor under continuous flow conditions, maintaining stable GVL productivity during 52-day time on stream operating at 3.5–5 bar, 80–95 °C and low H2/LA ratio (4–17:1 mol/mol). The exceptional catalytic performance and long term stability of the multifunctional carbocatalyst was attributed to the presence of highly active Ru(0) nanoparticles stabilized on N-doped carbon framework and acidic phosphates and RuOx/RuO2 sites, which promote LA hydrogenation and intramolecular esterification of 4-hydroxypenatonnic (4-HPA) in tandem, affording a high GVL selectivity. The catalyst’s combination of high productivity, long-term stability, and ability work under intensified setting in mid conditions highlight its potential for energy efficient GVL production at large scale.
